title: xlwings not working with OneDrive when the modules full folder location has a '-' in it
body:
macOS Monterey / xlwings 0.27.5 / Excel Office 365 / Python 3.9.7

---

I managed to locally run a macro successfully but I am having issues to run the same macro from OneDrive. I just copied and pasted the excel file and the python files, nothing changed.

On troubleshooting, I noticed that if the local folder containing the python files includes a '-' in its name, I get a `modulenotfound` error even if it was normally working before. However, if I replace the '-' by a '_', it works normally.

It happens that OneDrive changed its location from `/Users/abc/OneDrive` (xlwings used to work fine) to `/Users/abc/Library/CloudStorage/OneDrive-Personal/` which contains a '-' and now I'm getting this  `modulenotfound` error.

I found a workaround which is to add the python folder to the PYTHONPATH in the addin - inside Excel- but it has some side effects as this environment variable is global and shared among all the workbooks. So, everytime I open a different workbook, I need to update PYTHONPATH.

Before, each workbook had its own `xlwings.conf` with its own PYTHONPATH and I had to set it up once instead of everytime I open another different workbook.

I have tried several solutions from previous issues in github and stackoverflow but had no luck.

Any ideas on how to troubleshoot it further?

Thanks in advance

> I knew this time would come, I've updated all my workbooks removing formulas and vba macros and replacing them with Python code. I am now totally dependent on xlwings!

title: Google Sheets/Excel on the web bug: formats "1" etc as date
Sharepoint: don't force extending the sys.path by the workbook's directory
body:
Currently, `utils.prepare_sys_path` is called with RunPython whether it's required or not. It isn't necessary to call in case you have your code embedded or have your Python file on Python's module search path or provide the respective PYTHONPATH setting.

This leads to unnecessary issues when the file is stored on SharePoint and it can't figure out the local path.

title: Sharepoint path.name returning all lower case causing a conflict with conditional to book_name
body:
#### OS (e.g. Windows 10 or macOS Sierra)
Win 10
#### Versions of xlwings, Excel and Python (e.g. 0.11.8, Office 365, Python 3.7)
0.26.1, Excel 2201, Python 3.8.8
#### Describe your issue (incl. Traceback!)

Similar but different to issue #1810 
I found that when in our sharepoint environment (previous issue was in our onedrive environment that ended in .us) despite defining path in xlconfig, it could not find the workbook.  It appears that "path.name" in utils.py was returning a bookname all in lower case and comparing to a bookname that had capitalization.

I was able to fix by modifying line 480 in my code (479 in the unmodified 0.26.1 version) to convert both strings to ".lower()"

After this fix and issue #1810 fix I'm able to use XLwings in both our onedrive and sharepoint environments.

title: Onedrive domain ending in .us instead of .com

pattern = re.compile(r'https://[^-]*-my.sharepoint.us/[^/]*/[^/]*/[^/]*/(.*)')

title: Remaining SharePoint/OneDrive issue
body:
There are still some issues with SharePoint:

* capitalized dummies are "folders" though AAA is probably a "site-collection" ? see https://sharepointmaven.com/the-anatomy-of-a-sharepoint-url/). Also note the German variant to `/Documents`, see also: https://stackoverflow.com/a/65967886/918626

  This is **SharePoint**
  ```
  ActiveWorkbook.FullName:
  https://mycompany.sharepoint.com/sites/AAA/Freigegebene Dokumente/BBB/CCC/DDD/myfile.xlsm
  
  Local Path:
  C:\Users\myuser\my company\AAA - BBB\CCC\DDD\myfile.xlsm
  
  OneDrive Env var:
  C:\Users\myuser\my company
  ```
  
  The issue here is that `AAA/Freigegebene Dokumente/BBB` becomes `AAA - BBB` locally. This seems to be a `Office 365 Groups Site Collections`, see: https://sharepointmaven.com/site-collections-sharepoint/
  
  **Note**: if the code is embedded via xlwings PRO, it fails (but shouldn't), but can be worked around for the time being by providing a dummy value in the settings for `ONEDRIVE_WIN`, e.g. `%ONEDRIVE%`.

* `mybook.fullname` in the Python package hasn't been handled so far which can trip you off if you use it to find files that are next to the workbook

title: Settings hierarchy overrides empty values
body:
If you have an `xlwings.conf` sheet with all settings in there, empty values get overridden if you have them specified further down in the hierarchy (e.g. in a user config file). For example:

sheet
```
Conda Path | (empty)
```

user config file
```
"Conda Path","C:\some\path" 
```

Will use `C:\some\path` instead of using the empty value as it should.

body:
#### OS (e.g. Windows 10 or macOS Sierra)

#### Versions of xlwings, Excel and Python (e.g. 0.11.8, Office 365, Python 3.7)
20.7, Excel 365 Build 1908, Python 3.8.5
#### Describe your issue (incl. Traceback!)
The VBA code tries to load the pythonw.exe when show Console is set to False, but screws up the file path by replacing python with pythonw.

This results in a dll error that the file could not be found because the pythonw path (described below) does not exist.  Checking 'Show Console" to true fixes this.



Here in the VBA Code:
```
    PYTHON_WIN = GetConfig("INTERPRETER_WIN", "")
    If PYTHON_WIN = "" Then
        ' Legacy
        PYTHON_WIN = GetConfig("INTERPRETER", "pythonw")
    End If
    DEBUG_UDFS = GetConfig("DEBUG UDFS", False)

    ' Show Console requires python if True otherwise pythonw
    If GetConfig("SHOW CONSOLE", False) = True Then
        If InStr(1, PYTHON_WIN, "pythonw") > 0 Then
            PYTHON_WIN = Replace(PYTHON_WIN, "pythonw", "python")
        End If
    Else
        If InStr(1, PYTHON_WIN, "pythonw") = 0 Then
            PYTHON_WIN = Replace(PYTHON_WIN, "python", "pythonw")
        End If
    End If
```


It pulls in the interpreter, it then replaces python in the file path with pythonw.  This results in an invalid filepath:

`c:\users\<user>\appdata\local\programs\pythonw\pythonw38\pythonw.exe`

instead of:
`c:\users\<user>\appdata\local\programs\python\python38\pythonw.exe`

If I replace the line here:  

`PYTHON_WIN = Replace(PYTHON_WIN, "python", "pythonw")`

to

`PYTHON_WIN = Replace(PYTHON_WIN, "python.exe", "pythonw.exe")`

I can import UDFs without having to have the 'Show Console' set to True

```python
# Your traceback here

```

title: np.float64('nan') is not handled correctly
body:
Excel prints a 65535 instead (as in #15).

This is because of the following lines in prepare_xl_data_element (https://github.com/xlwings/xlwings/blob/171b10743224b60c85343d7df2fadf9be01e67fc/xlwings/_xlwindows.py#L1040)
```python
elif np and isinstance(x, np.generic):
        return float(x)
```
In that case, x is converted to a Python builtin float('nan'), but not to "".

I will try to produce a PR to fix this next week.

title: Sheet.names.add always on workbook level (Mac)
body:
# Overview

The `names` attribute of a `Sheet` is always empty on Mac with Excel 2011 and Python 3.6. This happens whether I make a new workbook from scratch or open an existing workbook that already contains named ranges. Adding a named range using the `names.add` method works from Excel's point of view—the cell takes on the name assigned to it—but not from Python's—`names` remains empty.

I do not have Windows. Is this reproducible in Windows?

# Reproducing the error

The following code makes a workbook in which cell A1 on the first worksheet is the named range "cell". If you run this code, you can check in Excel that it works. However the last line, in which `sheet.names` evaluates to the empty list, _should_ produce the list `[<Name 'cell': =Sheet1!$A$1>]`.

```python
>>> import xlwings
>>> workbook = xlwings.Book()
>>> sheet = workbook.sheets[0]
>>> sheet.names # Correctly empty
[]
>>> sheet.names.add("cell", "=Sheet1!$A$1")
<Name 'cell': =Sheet1!$A$1>
>>> sheet.names # Should be [<Name 'cell': =Sheet1!$A$1>] instead
[]
```

## Versions

Python 3.6.3 (default, Oct  4 2017, 06:09:15) 
xlwings 0.11.4
macOS 10.12.6
Excel for Mac 2011 version 14.2.0 (120402)

title: v0.10+Canopy 1.7.4: Crash on pictures.add() with new Canopy version
body:
I get a crash in the Python "kernel" when I call pictures.add() with a Matplotlib object.  This was working under a previous version of Canopy with XLWings 0.10.

The Windows help files are fairly unhelpful, no stack trace that I can identify.  I've not attached it since it contains some sensitive info. The error returned to Excel is "Run-time error '6' Overflow".

The crash occurs both when run from Excel and run from a standalone ipython session.  The update=True or False makes no difference.  Picture names and options don't seem to affect the crash, I stripped it down to:

        th_fig = p3nb.barplot_fig( mc.sim['total'], 'Total', mc.O_scen )
        th_plot = rsh.pictures.add( th_fig )

and the crash occurs on the pictures.add() statement.  To this point in the script numerous individual cells are updated, suggesting xlwings is behaving as expected to that point _(and xlwings has been great to this point, super product, BTW :-) )_.

This seems to be associated with the current 1.7.4 version of Canopy, and did not occur with an older version.  This vaguely suggests, to me, a linking issue with an associated library.  The only requirement I've seen that might be different is SciPy 0.18, which ships with the current Canopy, where I was using 0.17 before, but that's just a guess.

Environment is:

   * Windows 7 and 10,
   * Canopy Python 1.7.4.3348 (32-bit and 64-bit)
   * Excel 16.0 (Office 365 local install)
   * XLWings 0.10.

title: Windows: When opening a Book and Excel is not running, it opens additionally a Book1
body:
This behavior has been introduced with v0.9.0 because xlwings now allows you to control the app independently from a workbook. But in order to establish a connection using the current HWND approach, the app needs at least one workbook open which is the reason this currently happens.

We might be able to fix this though in case you're opening an existing book. See also #444.

title: Workbook option in Sheet class initialisation ineffective
body:
I wanted to open two workbook at the same time and to be able to write in a non active one. I write a small test describing the matter.
config:
xlwings 0.7.2
Excel 2007

```
# coding: utf8
import unittest
from xlwings import Workbook, Sheet, Range
from pywintypes import com_error


class TestBugSheet(unittest.TestCase):
    def setUp(self):
        self._origin = Workbook()
        self._destination = Workbook()

    def test_bug_sheet_init(self):
        origin_sheet = Sheet(1, wkb=self._origin)
        Range(origin_sheet, "A1").value = [["I am in the wrong Workbook"]]
        self._origin.close()
        result_sheet = Sheet(1, wkb=self._destination)
        self.assertEqual(Range(result_sheet, "A1").value, None)

    def tearDown(self):
        self._destination.close()
        try:
            self._origin.close()
        except com_error:
            pass
```

title: Attribute error when another excel instance has a process running
body:
Hi guys,

Take the scenario whereby I have two spreadsheets open, one on which I run my xlwings function (call it fileA)and the other on which I'm currently doing something else (call it fileB)

when I have something running on fileB be it a formula highlighted or a form window open, then  I run my xlwings  fct on file A, that usually generates an Attribute error :
AttributeError: <unknown>.Application

As a potential fix, I realised that
changing the exception handling in get_xl_apps() in file _xlwindows.py
from :

``` python
def get_xl_apps():
    xl_apps = []
    hwnds = get_excel_hwnds()
    for hwnd in hwnds:
        try:
            xl_app = get_xl_app_from_hwnd(hwnd)
            xl_apps.append(xl_app)
        except WindowsError:
            # This happens if the bare Excel Application is open without Workbook
            # i.e. there is no 'EXCEL7' child hwnd that would be necessary to make a connection
            pass
    return xl_apps
```

to 

``` python
def get_xl_apps():
    xl_apps = []
    hwnds = get_excel_hwnds()
    for hwnd in hwnds:
        try:
            xl_app = get_xl_app_from_hwnd(hwnd)
            xl_apps.append(xl_app)
        except  (WindowsError,AttributeError):
            # This happens if the bare Excel Application is open without Workbook
            # i.e. there is no 'EXCEL7' child hwnd that would be necessary to make a connection
            pass
    return xl_apps
```

tends to solve the problem

title: VBA Functions that are stored in Sheets don't return a value
body:
```
Function MyFunction(x)
    MyFunction = x * 2
End Function
```

This works when stored in a module:

```
>>> wb = Workbook.active()
>>> test1 = wb.macro("Module1.MyFunction")
>>> test1(2)
4
```

But returns `None` when stored in a Sheet object: `test1 = wb.macro("Sheet1.MyFunction")`

Calling Functions or Subs without return values works fine though even when stored in Sheets.

This seems to be a general issue with Excel interop: See: http://stackoverflow.com/q/3920343/918626

title: Spurious "multipe instances" warning
body:
As soon as I try to open a workbook which is already open (once!) I get a warning:

'This Workbook is open in multiple instances.'
'The connection was made with the one that was last active.'

FWIW, I am on Windows 10, using Office 2013.

This is annoying... I tried to trace the problem down but hit a brick wall as I don't know enough of the internals to understand exactly what happens. Here are a few tidbits I figured. Hope it helps.

I just figured that get_duplicate_fullnames() always returns all open files (whether they are opened in one instance or several), that get_xl_apps() returns me **one more** xl_app than the number of workbooks I opened and that get_all_open_xl_workbooks() seems to return all open workbooks **for each xl_app**.

So for example, if I have 3 documents open:
- get_duplicate_fullnames() returns all 3 documents
- get_xl_apps() returns 4 instances.
- each call to get_all_open_xl_workbooks(xl_app) returns all 3 documents, so the
  open_xl_workbooks list at the end of get_duplicate_fullnames contains 12 elements, which obviously contains duplicates...

title: xlwings.applescript doesn't get placed into the right folder when installed with sudo
body:
Hi. Love the software but on Excel 2016 v 15.20, Mac OSX 10.11.3 I had to dig around with Ron de Bruin site and do the following to get the xlwings.applescript going even after the xlwings runpython install

To install xlwings.applescript
Open a Finder Window
Hold the Alt key when you press on Go in the Finder menu bar
Click on Library
Click on Application Scripts (if it exists; if not create this folder)
Click on com.microsoft.Excel (if it exists; if not create this folder) note: Capital letter E (I had to create this folder)
Copy the xlwings.applescript file from the xlwings package to this (maybe new) folder.
(Note the xlwings.applescript is a system file so on finder you have to search for it with an additional 'system files ARE included' option to find it)
Also for me in the xlwings VBA default parameters,  Thisworkbook.path does not work - I have to put in the full path to my python code as PYTHONPATH - i.e. /Users/Mark/Downloads/myproject/

Thank you

title: workbook.active_sheet is set at __init__ time while it should be a property
body:
The active_sheet attribute of a Workbook is set at **init** time. 
If the user activates a sheet with Sheet(...).activate() the active_sheet is not updated.
As the user could also activate a sheet via Sheet().xl_sheet.Activate(), it would be better to have active_sheet as a property (dynamically calculated).

title: get_excel_hwnds throws an error in case no Excel application is running
Range doesn't preserve kwargs when used with methods/properties that return a Range
body:
I see often in the code the structure

```
    return Range(xlplatform.get_worksheet_name(self.xl_sheet), (self.row1, self.col1), (row2, col2), **self.kwargs)
```

which create a new Range object based on an existing Range object + change in some attributes (usually row/col).

An issue with this construct is that if one changes attributes like asarray or atleast_2d from elsewhere than in the constructor, it does not preserve it, for example

```
rng = Range("A1", atleast_2d=True)
rng.atleast_2d=False
print rng.offset(0,0).atleast_2d # ==> print True while I would expect False
```

This is due to the self.kwargs not being updated after construction.

I wonder if it could not be simpler and more robust to have a "copy" method that would simply copy the Range object as well as a "set" method allowing to have chained setattr.

The code above would look like

```
    return self.copy().set(row1=self.row1, col1=self.col1, row2=self.row2, col2=self.col2)
```

The copy would be a simple call to the standard copy.copy method

```
def copy(self):
    return copy.copy(self)
```

and the set would be

```
def set(self, **kwargs):
    for k,v in kwargs.iteritems():
        setattr(self, k, v)
    return self
```

To make it shorted, we could also have a copy that set at the same time

```
def copy(self, **kwargs):
    return copy.copy(self).set(**kwargs)
```

What do you think ?

PS: feel free to tell me if there are issues you want to tackle yourself. I let you know when I start working on some fix anyway to avoid duplicating efforts.

title: Range.resize is wrong in case row_size or column_size is None
body:
I would expect that

```
Range("A1:C5").resize(row_size=1)
```

would give a range covering "A1:C1" but it gives the range "A1" (ie if column_size=None, it is assumed to be = 1).
In the code of the resize method, the "if row_size" is maybe better covered by a "if row_size is not None" to catch the case where the size=0 (which should be an error I guess) and ditto for the column_size

title: bug if PYTHONPATH contains multiple directories

If PYTHONPATH contains multiple directories separated by ";" the RunCommand is not correct.

```
    RunCommand = "python -c ""import sys; sys.path.append(r'" & PYTHONPATH & "'); " & Command & """ "
```

can be replaced by

```
    RunCommand = "python -c ""import sys; sys.path.extend(r'" & PYTHONPATH & ".split(";")'); " & Command & """ "
```

title: Refactor named ranges to work with Sheet/Workbook scopes
body:
This may be related to issue #156 but not sure.

In Excel, a named range can be defined either at workbook scope (per default when typing a name for a range) or at worksheet scope (when creating the name through the Name Manager GUI and choosing a sheet as scope OR when typing a name for a range that already exists at workbook scope).
The range referred by a named range (irrespective of the scope : workbook or sheet) can any range in any sheet of the workbook.

It could be useful to have access to the named range at sheet scope through the notation:

```
sh.names
```

as we have currently for named range at workbook scope with

```
wb.names
```

title: problem with same workbook opened in two different Excel instances
body:
If the exact same workbook is opened in two different Excel instances, calling xlwings from one of the two will "fail" as xlwings will get back the first excel workbook available in the ROT. Therefore running the python code on the wrong workbook. This leads to weird behavior for the user.

A workable solution to at least detect the issue maybe to pass the Application.Hwnd as 4th argument to python (besides the ["-c", workbook path, "from_xl"] arguments). This would then allow to check in the Workbook.caller() function that the returned workbook wb has wb.xl_app.Hwnd == Hwnd from Excel.

Better would be to get directly the proper workbook (instead of just throwing an error in case of issue as here above) using the window handle of the workbook/excel window (see answer of Peter Thornton in https://social.msdn.microsoft.com/Forums/office/en-US/e3e99712-01a7-483e-bf0e-52bb1f94889c/how-to-use-accessibleobjectfromwindow-api-in-vba-to-get-excel-application-object-from-excel?forum=exceldev for VBA example). But I could not succeed in transforming this code into proper python code to propose a full blown solution under windows.
This approach could also allow to get back the Excel that is the "active" one (using the Hwnd of the caller Excel and the code referenced here above).

title: Various issues with  timezone aware datetime objects (datetime, numpy, pandas)
body:
Replicate with the following code: 
from xlwings import Workbook, Range
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
dt = np.datetime64(1434149887000,'ms')
data_list = np.empty(1, dtype=np.float64)
data_list[:] = 1
dti = pd.DatetimeIndex(data=[dt],tz='GMT')
df = pd.DataFrame(data=data_list, index=dti, columns=['A'])
wb = Workbook()
Range('A1',wkb=wb).value = df
The code will work if line dti = pd.DatetimeIndex(data=[dt],tz='GMT') is changed to dti = pd.DatetimeIndex(data=[dt]). We found that it hangs during the last line of the main.py Range value method: xlplatform.set_value(xlplatform.get_range_from_indices(self.xl_sheet, self.row1, self.col1, row2, col2), data).

title: Workbook.save() should just save the current Workbook if previously saved
body: currently it always saved to the cwd if no path is provided.

title: Resolve the close/reopen issue in the case the file is opened from Python
body:
using `wb = Workbook('fullname.xlsm')` -> see #10 

The thing is, unlike when called from Excel, here we don't know if the file is open or not, we also don't know if it is the active file or not, so using `GetActiveObject` will be difficult. 

Maybe just say that for this file, it's impossible to make a connection based on the filename, but something like active workbook (once it's implemented...) will work.

Note that this is only ever an issue if you interact with a Workbook that has macros. Since this will most likely be when you're putting together an xlwings powered Workbook, you can work around it by using the `Workbook.set_mock_caller()` in conjuction with `Workbook.caller()`, see http://docs.xlwings.org/debugging.html

title: Mac: Error pop-up isn't shown on Python 3
body:
Reason is that in Python 3, buffering of stderr is the default while in Python 2 it is not: http://python.6.x6.nabble.com/Buffering-of-sys-stdout-and-sys-stderr-in-python3-and-documentation-td1411111.html

Can be fixed with running `python -u`.

title: Range('Sheet1', 'NamedRange').value assignment for sparse first column issue
body:
When assigning values to a variable using a named range, in a case where the first column has missing values, the value reading stops at the first empty cell. It should capture the entire named range.

For example for a named range that looks like this and extends from [Heading1:Data32]

```
Heading1  Heading2
Data11      Data12
[empty]     Data22
[empty]     Data32
```

The command:

```
$ data = Range('Sheet1', 'NamedRange').value
```

Results in only capturing the first 2 rows.  One would expect it to capture all of the data in the 'NamedRange'.

title: Windows: Fix VBA issue on Excel 64bit

`Private Declare Function system Lib ...` fails on Excel 64bit (Windows):

```
 Compile error:
 The code in this project must be updated for use on 64-bit systems.
```

This code is only used in Excel for Mac so should be easy to fix. As a temporary workaround, it can be simply commented out on Windows.

title: Mac: CleanUp macro causes troubles when run from Python
body:
It's causing errors when driven from Python. It may be enough though to simply ignore errors in Show Log_file block in case it doesn't exist:

```
'Show the LOG_FILE as MsgBox if not empty
On Error Resume Next
If ReadFile(LOG_FILE) <> "" Then
    Call ShowError(LOG_FILE)
End If
On Error GoTo 0
```

Correct Line 472 and possibly other ocurrencies (TODO: factor out the check for single cells).

```
# Simple Lists: Turn into list of lists
if isinstance(data, list) and (isinstance(data[0], (numbers.Number, string_types, time_types) or data[0] is None):
```

title: scalar np.nan are not being handled correctly
body: Excel prints a 65535 instead. Currently this is only handled for `np.nan` within numpy arrays. Note that `np.nan` is of type `numbers.Number`

title: Win: Protected View causes file to close and reopen
body: When the samples are downloaded from the internet and depending on the Excel setting under `File > Options > Trust Center > Trust Center Settings...`, Excel can give you a `Security Warning - Enable Content`. If that is the case, the excecution of the macro will end with hiding the Workbook completely. In that case, only a restart of Excel helps. A workaround is to close/reopen the Workbook just after enabling the Security Warning.

title: Frozen executables on overly restrictive environments
body:
The standalone version (frozen executable) can be blocked to execute on very restrictive (corporate) environments.
Currently it just hangs doing nothing - it should fail with an error message.
